metadata.titleEn: Moderate resolution MODIS river lake ice cover dataset in high latitude region of northern hemisphere (2002-2018)
metadata.description: The medium-resolution MODIS river and lake ice phenology data set in the high latitudes of the northern hemisphere from 2002 to 2019 is based on the Normalized Difference Snow Index (NDSI) data of the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer(MODIS). Daily lake iceextent and coverage under clear-sky conditions was examined byemploying the conventional SNOWMAP algorithm, and thoseunder cloud cover conditions were re-determined using the temporal and spatial continuity of lake surface conditions througha series of steps.The lake ice phenology information obtained in this dataset was highly consistent with that from passive microwave data at an average correlation coefficient of 0.91 and an RMSE value varying from 0.07 to 0.13.
metadata.instructions: The data include the daily lake ice cover of the frozen lakes in Eurasia and the daily river ice coverage in the Irtysh - EBI River Basin. The data of lake ice and river ice are separately stored in the folder of river ice and lake ice. The data format is TIF and the projection is WGS-84. The name of the file is“ yyyyddd.tif ”where yyyy stands for year, ddd stands for Julian date, 2003001.tif is the coverage of lake ice or river ice on January 1, 2003.

background: Known as the "Roof of the World," the Tibetan Plateau has an average elevation of more than 2,000 m and an abundance of lakes. Lake ice is an indicator of changes in lake environments; moreover, it is also one of the key Environmental Climate Variables (ECVs) in the Global Climate Observing System (GCOS). However, the existing in situ lake ice observation data for the Tibetan Plateau is severely limited due to the remoteness, harsh eco-environmental conditions, and thin atmosphere in this region. At present, many researchers have studied the lake ice phenology based on remote sensing data and released four data sets, but the dataset derived primarily from coarse resolution passive microwave observations is not effective for monitoring the numerous small lakes in the Tibetan Plateau.
research objective: Therefore, a comprehensive lake ice monitoring dataset is urgently needed to compensate for this observation shortage. The dataset presented herein was prepared using the MODIS Normalized Difference Snow Index (NDSI) with a spatial resolution of 500 m as input for the NDSI snow cover algorithm SNOWMAP in order to detect the lake ice coverage under daily clear sky conditions. This method was used to calculate and classify the daily lake ice characteristics for the maximum number of lakes within the Tibetan Plateau from 2002 to 2018.
challenges: The existing in situ lake ice observation data for the Tibetan Plateau is severely limited due to the remoteness, harsh eco-environmental conditions, and thin atmosphere in this region. The dataset derived primarily from coarse resolution passive microwave observations is not effective for monitoring the numerous small lakes in the Tibetan Plateau. The SNOWMAP algorithm tends to incorrectly identify lake ice pixels under clear sky conditions, which indicates that an updated algorithm for the snow/ice recognition is needed.
methods: The MODIS data pre-processing was carried out at the UTM/WGS84 system with steps of image splicing, projection, transformation, and image cropping. The NDSI snow cover algorithm SNOWMAP was used to estimate the daily lake ice on/off at a single pixel under clear sky, and then a series of further processes was conducted under cloudy conditions based on spatial and temporal continuity of lake surface conditions. Based on the complementary morning and afternoon satellite observations, daily lake ice/water data under cloud cover conditions was synthesized based on the following three rules. The cloud-covered pixels were re-identified using spatial adjacent relationships and its spatial continuity based on their proximity. Aiming to obtain the inventory of lake ice/water change characteristics for every single lake, a further time series filter was conducted for each lake with ice, water, and cloud.
dataset: The MODIS Snow Cover Daily L3 Global 500 m Grid dataset was used as the input data, which was obtained from the US National Snow and Ice Data Center, including MODIS/Terra morning acquisition data (MOD10A1) and MODIS/Aqua afternoon acquisition data (MYD10A1). As a result, the lake ice extent data with partial cloud cover were obtained for 5,834 days, and lake ice, water and cloud coverage for each single lake, which was defined as the ratio of extent of lake ice and lake area, were obtained accordingly. Of total 2612 examined lakes in Tibetan Plateau, the 5834 days’ time series of cloud free time series of lake ice coverage for 625 lakes with areas larger than 3 km2 were effectively recorded.
findings: The lake ice phenology information obtained in this paper was highly consistent with that from passive microwave data at an average correlation coefficient of 0.91 and an RMSE value varying from 0.07 to 0.13. The present dataset is more effective at detecting lake ice parameters for smaller lakes than the coarse resolution passive microwave remote sensing observations.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to monitor lake ice coverage in remote and harsh environmental conditions?
Example.Answer: A data collection method involves using the MODIS Normalized Difference Snow Index (NDSI) with a spatial resolution of 500 m as input for the NDSI snow cover algorithm SNOWMAP to detect lake ice coverage under daily clear sky conditions.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting lake ice observation data in high-altitude regions?
Example.Answer: A challenge in collecting lake ice observation data in high-altitude regions is the severe limitation of in situ observations due to remoteness, harsh eco-environmental conditions, and thin atmosphere, which affects the effectiveness of coarse resolution passive microwave observations for monitoring numerous small lakes.

Example.Question: Could you illustrate an example of how a dataset can be synthesized to manage cloud cover conditions while monitoring lake ice coverage?
Example.Answer: A dataset can be synthesized to manage cloud cover conditions by utilizing complementary morning and afternoon satellite observations. Cloud-covered pixels are re-identified using spatial adjacent relationships and spatial continuity based on proximity, and a further time series filter is applied to obtain data on lake ice, water, and cloud coverage for each lake.

Definition.Question: What is the SNOWMAP algorithm used for in the context of lake ice monitoring?
Definition.Answer: The SNOWMAP algorithm is used to detect lake ice coverage under daily clear sky conditions using the MODIS Normalized Difference Snow Index (NDSI) data. It estimates the daily lake ice on/off status at a single pixel and is further refined to account for cloudy conditions based on the spatial and temporal continuity of lake surface conditions.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with in situ lake ice observation data collection in remote regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: Challenges include the severe limitation of existing in situ lake ice observation data due to the remoteness, harsh eco-environmental conditions, and thin atmosphere in the Tibetan Plateau. Additionally, datasets derived from coarse resolution passive microwave observations are not effective for monitoring the numerous small lakes in the area.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using MODIS Normalized Difference Snow Index (NDSI) for lake ice monitoring compare to those using coarse resolution passive microwave observations in terms of effectiveness for small lakes?
Comparison.Answer: The MODIS NDSI method is more effective for detecting lake ice parameters for smaller lakes compared to coarse resolution passive microwave observations, as it provides better spatial resolution and is capable of monitoring numerous small lakes effectively.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of collecting in situ lake ice observation data on the Tibetan Plateau differ from the challenges of using remote sensing data for the same purpose?
Comparison.Answer: In situ data collection on the Tibetan Plateau is limited by remoteness, harsh eco-environmental conditions, and thin atmosphere, whereas remote sensing using MODIS and similar technologies can be affected by cloud cover and the need for algorithm adjustments to accurately identify lake ice under varying conditions.

Interpretation.Question: How can the spatial and temporal continuity of lake surface conditions be leveraged to improve the accuracy of detecting lake ice coverage under cloudy conditions?
Interpretation.Answer: The spatial and temporal continuity of lake surface conditions can be leveraged by utilizing the spatial adjacent relationships and proximity of cloud-covered pixels, which are re-identified and synthesized based on complementary morning and afternoon satellite observations. This approach helps in estimating the daily lake ice coverage even under cloudy conditions, by applying a time series filter for each lake's ice, water, and cloud characteristics.

Interpretation.Question: What potential challenges might arise from using moderate-resolution MODIS data to monitor small lakes in high latitude regions, and how can these challenges be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: The potential challenges include the difficulty in accurately monitoring numerous small lakes due to the coarse resolution of passive microwave data and the tendency of the SNOWMAP algorithm to incorrectly identify lake ice pixels under clear sky conditions. These challenges can be addressed by improving the algorithm for snow/ice recognition and using spatial and temporal data continuity to re-identify cloud-covered pixels and synthesize lake ice data effectively.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of MODIS data with other remote sensing technologies enhance the monitoring of lake ice phenology in remote and harsh environments?
Interpretation.Answer: Integration with other remote sensing technologies could enhance monitoring by providing complementary data that fills gaps left by MODIS in terms of resolution and cloud cover limitations. It could also help refine the algorithms used for snow/ice recognition, allowing for more accurate monitoring of smaller lakes and regions with harsh environmental conditions, thus addressing the limited in situ observation capabilities.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes limitations in existing in situ lake ice observation data collection in remote regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The existing in situ lake ice observation data for the Tibetan Plateau is severely limited due to the remoteness, harsh eco-environmental conditions, and thin atmosphere in this region.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might datasets derived from coarse resolution passive microwave observations be ineffective for monitoring small lakes?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The dataset derived primarily from coarse resolution passive microwave observations is not effective for monitoring the numerous small lakes in the Tibetan Plateau because these observations lack the resolution needed to accurately capture the ice coverage of smaller lakes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons for inaccuracies in lake ice pixel identification using the SNOWMAP algorithm under clear sky conditions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The SNOWMAP algorithm tends to incorrectly identify lake ice pixels under clear sky conditions, which indicates that an updated algorithm for the snow/ice recognition is needed.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using MODIS data with a 500 m resolution for lake ice monitoring in high-latitude areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using MODIS data with a 500 m resolution allows for effective monitoring of lake ice parameters, especially for smaller lakes, compared to coarse resolution passive microwave observations. This approach helps overcome limitations related to the remoteness and harsh conditions of the Tibetan Plateau, providing a comprehensive dataset for lake ice monitoring.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the use of SNOWMAP algorithm under clear sky conditions impact the accuracy of lake ice detection?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The SNOWMAP algorithm under clear sky conditions tends to incorrectly identify lake ice pixels. This indicates a need for an updated algorithm for snow/ice recognition, as the current method may not always accurately classify lake ice characteristics, affecting overall dataset accuracy.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of combining MODIS morning and afternoon satellite observations for data synthesis under cloud cover conditions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Combining MODIS morning and afternoon satellite observations allows for the synthesis of daily lake ice/water data even under cloud cover conditions. This approach helps re-identify cloud-covered pixels using spatial continuity, thereby providing a more comprehensive and accurate dataset for lake ice monitoring over time.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it essential to develop a comprehensive lake ice monitoring dataset using MODIS data for high-latitude regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: A comprehensive lake ice monitoring dataset is essential to compensate for the observation shortage in areas like the Tibetan Plateau, where in situ observations are limited due to remoteness and harsh conditions. The dataset aids in detecting lake ice coverage under clear sky conditions, enhancing the understanding of lake environments and their changes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of employing the SNOWMAP algorithm in determining lake ice coverage for high-latitude regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of using the SNOWMAP algorithm is to accurately detect lake ice coverage under daily clear sky conditions. This approach aims to calculate and classify daily lake ice characteristics across numerous lakes, addressing the limitations of coarse resolution passive microwave observations in monitoring smaller lakes.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why pursue an updated algorithm for snow/ice recognition in the context of remote sensing data collection for lake ice monitoring?
Goal Orientation.Answer: An updated algorithm for snow/ice recognition is necessary because the SNOWMAP algorithm can incorrectly identify lake ice pixels under clear sky conditions. Improving the algorithm enhances the accuracy of lake ice monitoring, which is crucial for developing datasets that effectively represent lake ice phenology.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in utilizing MODIS data to detect lake ice coverage under clear sky conditions using the NDSI snow cover algorithm?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The MODIS data pre-processing involves steps such as image splicing, projection, transformation, and image cropping. Then, the NDSI snow cover algorithm SNOWMAP is applied to estimate daily lake ice on/off at a single pixel under clear sky conditions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can daily lake ice/water data be synthesized under cloud cover conditions using complementary satellite observations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Daily lake ice/water data under cloud cover conditions is synthesized using complementary morning and afternoon satellite observations. This process is based on three rules involving spatial adjacent relationships, spatial continuity, and a time series filter for each lake to identify lake ice, water, and cloud coverage.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are necessary to ensure the accurate classification of lake ice, water, and cloud coverage for individual lakes, particularly under cloud-covered conditions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To accurately classify lake ice, water, and cloud coverage, cloud-covered pixels are re-identified using spatial adjacent relationships and spatial continuity. Further, a time series filter is conducted for each lake to obtain the inventory of lake ice/water change characteristics, ensuring accurate classification despite cloud cover.

Enablement.Question: What techniques enable the accurate detection of lake ice coverage in remote and harsh environments like the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The use of the MODIS Normalized Difference Snow Index (NDSI) with a spatial resolution of 500 m as input for the SNOWMAP algorithm allows for the detection of lake ice coverage under daily clear sky conditions. Additional processing under cloudy conditions based on spatial and temporal continuity helps refine the detection.

Enablement.Question: How does the application of spatial and temporal continuity principles enhance data collection for lake ice monitoring under cloudy conditions?
Enablement.Answer: Spatial and temporal continuity principles are applied to re-identify cloud-covered pixels using spatial adjacent relationships and proximity. This helps synthesize daily lake ice/water data from complementary satellite observations, enabling effective recording of lake ice coverage even when cloud cover is present.

Enablement.Question: What factors contribute to the effective monitoring of small lakes' ice coverage using remote sensing data, overcoming limitations of coarse resolution observations?
Enablement.Answer: The dataset derived from the MODIS Snow Cover Daily L3 Global 500 m Grid dataset, which includes MODIS/Terra and MODIS/Aqua data, is more effective at detecting lake ice parameters for smaller lakes due to higher spatial resolution compared to coarse resolution passive microwave observations. This approach allows for more accurate monitoring of small lakes' ice coverage.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be challenging to achieve consistent lake ice detection using remote sensing data in high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: The challenges arise from the remoteness, harsh eco-environmental conditions, and thin atmosphere in the region, which limit in situ observations. Additionally, the SNOWMAP algorithm tends to incorrectly identify lake ice pixels under clear sky conditions, indicating the need for an updated algorithm for more accurate snow/ice recognition.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated challenges in accurately monitoring small lakes using coarse resolution passive microwave observations?
Expectation.Answer: Coarse resolution passive microwave observations are not effective for monitoring numerous small lakes due to their limited ability to detect finer details necessary for accurately capturing lake ice parameters, particularly for smaller water bodies.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected benefits of employing MODIS data with the NDSI snow cover algorithm for lake ice monitoring in high-latitude regions?
Expectation.Answer: Using MODIS data with the NDSI snow cover algorithm allows for a more comprehensive lake ice monitoring dataset, which compensates for the observation shortage in remote regions. It provides effective detection of lake ice parameters, especially for smaller lakes, and achieves high consistency with passive microwave data, as indicated by an average correlation coefficient of 0.91 and RMSE values between 0.07 to 0.13.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you think the SNOWMAP algorithm is in accurately identifying lake ice pixels under varying sky conditions, and what improvements could be made for enhanced precision?
Judgmental.Answer: The SNOWMAP algorithm has a tendency to incorrectly identify lake ice pixels under clear sky conditions, indicating that an updated algorithm for snow/ice recognition is needed.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand how a dataset can accurately monitor numerous small lakes using remote sensing when coarse resolution observations seem ineffective.
Assertion.Answer: The dataset uses the MODIS Normalized Difference Snow Index (NDSI) with a spatial resolution of 500 m and the SNOWMAP algorithm to detect daily lake ice coverage under clear sky conditions, which is more effective at monitoring small lakes compared to coarse resolution passive microwave observations.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the methods used to identify lake ice coverage under cloudy conditions.
Assertion.Answer: Under cloudy conditions, a process based on the spatial and temporal continuity of lake surface conditions is used. This includes re-identifying cloud-covered pixels using spatial adjacent relationships and their continuity, complemented by morning and afternoon satellite observations to synthesize daily lake ice/water data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced when using remote sensing data to monitor lake ice coverage in high-latitude regions and suggest potential solutions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include the remoteness, harsh eco-environmental conditions, and thin atmosphere of regions like the Tibetan Plateau, which limit in situ observations. Additionally, datasets derived from coarse resolution passive microwave observations are not effective for monitoring numerous small lakes. The SNOWMAP algorithm may incorrectly identify lake ice pixels under clear sky conditions, indicating a need for an updated snow/ice recognition algorithm. Potential solutions could involve improving the algorithm for better accuracy and utilizing complementary satellite observations to enhance data reliability.

Request/Directive.Question: Please suggest methods to enhance the accuracy of lake ice detection using MODIS data under varying atmospheric conditions.
Request/Directive.Answer: To enhance accuracy, the MODIS data pre-processing includes image splicing, projection, transformation, and cropping. The NDSI snow cover algorithm SNOWMAP estimates daily lake ice under clear sky conditions, while further processes under cloudy conditions rely on spatial and temporal continuity. Complementary morning and afternoon satellite observations were synthesized using spatial adjacent relationships and proximity rules to re-identify cloud-covered pixels. A time series filter for each lake helps obtain an inventory of lake ice/water changes, enhancing detection accuracy under varying conditions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential data sources and methods for expanding datasets of lake ice coverage in the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential data sources include the MODIS Snow Cover Daily L3 Global 500 m Grid dataset, comprising MODIS/Terra morning acquisition data (MOD10A1) and MODIS/Aqua afternoon acquisition data (MYD10A1). These data sources provided lake ice extent data for 5,834 days, covering 2,612 lakes. Methods for expansion could involve increasing the spatial resolution to capture smaller lakes more effectively and exploring additional satellite observations to fill data gaps under cloud cover conditions.
